concern:
I’m a senior in college doing a dual degree (not a double major) in Computer Science and Biomathematics. I was supposed to graduate in the summer for both but I wasn’t able to get into a Physics 1 course this spring, that I need to take Physics 2 in the summer, which means I will be delayed a whole semester because of one class. With the classes im taking right now in the spring I finish my CS degree, and then I have 2 clases left plus physics 1 and 2 for my BM degree. My question is: can i graduate from my CS bachelor before the BM? It feels like a waste that now I have to wait until the end of the year to finish when I have almost nothing left, and I also don’t want to just waste all my work these 4 years and not do BM. At least graduating from CS I can get a decent job and not waste all those months
Any advice is appreciated!!

dialogue_total.statement: It sounds like you're feeling overwhelmed and unsure about how to move forward. That can be a difficult place to be. Can you tell me more about what's been going on?

I'm feeling really stressed about a scheduling issue that's delaying my graduation for one of my degrees, making me question if I can finish the other one first. It's tough because I don't want to waste all the hard work I've put in over the past four years.

It's completely understandable to feel stressed and uncertain in this situation. You've invested so much time and effort into your degrees, and it's natural to want to see that hard work pay off. Can you tell me a bit more about the scheduling issue that's causing the delay?

I'm really frustrated because the scheduling conflict is preventing me from taking a necessary class on time, which is pushing back my graduation for one degree. It's making me anxious about whether I can complete the other degree first without losing all the progress I've made.

It sounds like you're caught in a tough spot, and it's understandable to feel frustrated and anxious. You're trying to balance two degrees, and this scheduling conflict is throwing a wrench in your plans. It's a lot to deal with, and it's okay to feel overwhelmed. Have you talked to your academic advisor or anyone else at your school about possible solutions?

Yes, I've talked to the therapists at my school about this to help manage the stress it's causing. I'm still concerned about whether academic options exist to address the delay without derailing my progress.

It's great that you're seeking support from the school therapists to manage your stress. I can understand how the uncertainty about academic options might be weighing on you. In addition to working with the therapists, have you considered scheduling a meeting with your academic advisor to explore potential solutions? They may have insights or alternatives you haven't considered yet, and it could be helpful to discuss your concerns directly with them.

I've already discussed my concerns with my academic advisor, but I'm still anxious about whether any solutions can help me graduate from my CS degree first without further delays. It's frustrating to feel stuck like this after all the effort I've put in.

It seems like you're feeling stuck and anxious despite having taken steps to address your concerns. It can be disheartening to face obstacles after putting in so much effort. Remember that it's okay to feel overwhelmed, and it's important to acknowledge your feelings as you navigate this challenging situation. While you've already spoken with your advisor, have you considered reaching out to other faculty members or the department head to explore additional options or resources that may help you find a solution?

I haven't reached out to other faculty members or the department head yet, as I'm focused on avoiding further delays. I'm open to exploring that option if it could help me graduate from my CS degree sooner.

It's good to hear that you're open to exploring more options to help you graduate from your CS degree on time. Reaching out to other faculty members or the department head might provide you with additional support or resources you haven't considered. Remember, it's essential to communicate your concerns clearly and advocate for your academic goals. It might be helpful to prepare for these conversations by writing down your thoughts, questions, and desired outcomes. By taking these steps, you're actively working towards a solution that could alleviate your stress and help you achieve your academic aspirations.

I appreciate the suggestion to prepare for those conversations, as it could help me stay focused on graduating from my CS degree without further setbacks. I'm worried that any additional delays might undermine all the hard work I've done so far.

It's natural to worry about potential setbacks, but remember that you've already accomplished a great deal in your academic journey. As you prepare to reach out to other faculty members or the department head, keep in mind that you're doing so to protect the progress you've made and find a solution that works for you. It's essential to maintain open communication with those who can support you in achieving your goals. Would you like to discuss some strategies for initiating these conversations and presenting your concerns effectively?
Yes, I'd like to discuss strategies for initiating those conversations effectively. This could help me address my concerns about graduating from my CS degree without further delays.

It's great that you're eager to learn about effective communication strategies. Here are some steps you can follow to prepare for conversations with faculty members or the department head

1. Clearly state your concerns and goals, making sure to emphasize your dedication to graduating from your CS degree on time.
2. Be prepared with specific examples of the challenges you've faced and the efforts you've made to overcome them.
3. Approach the conversation with a collaborative mindset, expressing your willingness to work together to find a solution that benefits both parties.
4. Be open to feedback and suggestions, and be prepared to ask questions to clarify any points of confusion.

By following these steps, you'll be better equipped to engage in productive conversations that can help you navigate the challenges you're facing and achieve your academic goals. I wish you the best of luck, and remember that you've already accomplished a lot in your academic journey. Keep up the hard work!

Thank you for the strategies I'll use them to discuss graduating from my CS degree on time and avoid any more delays that could waste my hard work. I appreciate your support as I wrap up this session.
